questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of innate immunity?
questions.solution:
B cell is not a component of innate immunity. It is a component of adaptive immunity.

Innate immunity refers to the body’s natural immunity. It is a built-in defence system that is present since birth. It differs from adaptive immunity in that it does not require any prior sensitization to an antigen.

The major components of innate immunity are as follows:

  • Epithelial barriers that block the entry of microbes
  • Phagocytic cells (neutrophils and macrophages)
  • Natural killer (NK) cells
  • Dendritic cell
  • Cells that can sense and react to microbes - mast cells, epithelial and endothelial cells
  • Plasma proteins - complement system factors, mannose-binding lectin, and C-reactive protein
  • Innate lymphoid cells  
  • Lung surfactant

questions.text: Antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC) is seen with:
questions.solution:
Antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC) is mediated by NK cells, neutrophils and eosinophils (killing certain parasitic worms like helminths via IgE antibodies).

In ADCC, cells/ antigens are coated with IgG antibodies. These are killed by effector cells like NK cells and macrophages. These effector cells bind to the target by their receptors for the Fc fragment of IgG and cell lysis proceeds without phagocytosis.

questions.text: Which of the following occurs due to gain-of-function mutations in NOD-Like receptors?
questions.solution:
The gain of function mutations in NOD-Like receptors (NLRs) result in periodic fever syndromes called autoinflammatory syndromes.

They are a group of clinical conditions characterised by recurrent inflammatory episodes. This disorder is marked by abnormally increased inflammation, mediated predominantly by cells and molecules of the innate immune system, with a significant host predisposition. 

NOD-like receptors are cytosolic receptors that signal via a cytosolic multiprotein complex called the inflammasome. This activates caspase-1 that generates biologically active form of interleukin-1 (IL-1). IL-1 is a mediator of inflammation that recruits leukocytes and induces fever. The autoinflammatory syndromes respond very well to treatment with IL-1 antagonists.

Note: Autoimmune diseases result from T and B-lymphocyte reactions against self-antigens.

questions.text: What is the normal CD4+: CD8+ T lymphocyte ratio?
questions.solution:
Normal CD4+: CD8+ T lymphocyte ratio is 2:1. Approximately 60% of mature T cells are CD4+ and about 30% are CD8+. 

T-lymphocytes (thymus-derived cells) constitute 60–70% of peripheral blood lymphocytes. T-cell progenitors are derived from the bone marrow, but travel to the thymus, where they mature. T cells can be divided into three main subtypes:

Type of T cell

Function

Helper T cell (CD4+)

Helps B lymphocytes to make antibodies and activate other leukocytes to destroy microbes

Cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CTLs or CD8+)

Kill infected cells

Regulatory T cells

Limit immune responses and prevent reactions against self-antigens.

They are located in the paracortical areas of lymph nodes and the periarteriolar sheaths of the spleen. They have an antigen-specific T-cell receptors (TCR) which have alpha/beta polypeptide chains components. Demonstration of TCR gene rearrangement by southern blot is a molecular marker of T-cell lineage. 

The CD molecules present on T cells are CD1, CD2, CD3, CD4, CD5, CD7, CD8 and CD28. CD3 is involved in signal transduction and is also called a pan T-cell marker. CD40 ligand on the surface is required for B-cell activation and induction of immunoglobulin.

questions.text: Which of the following is not expressed in the B-cell receptor complex?
questions.solution:
CD86 is a protein expressed on antigen-presenting cells, and not B-cell receptor complex. This protein provides costimulatory signals necessary for T-cell activation and survival.

B-cell receptor complex expresses the following:

  • CD79a and CD79b - essential for signal transduction through the antigen receptor
  • CD21 or CR2 - complement receptor (recognize complement products during innate immune response) and Epstein–Barr virus (EBV) receptor
  • CD40 - receives signals from helper T cells

Other B cell-associated markers are CD10 (CALLA), CD19, CD20, CD22, CD23.

questions.text: Which of the following are the most important antigen-presenting cells?
questions.solution:
Dendritic cells or interdigitating dendritic cells are the most important antigen-presenting cells. They initiate T-cell responses against protein antigens.

They are located in the epithelium and interstitium. They express many receptors for capturing and responding to microbes (and other antigens), including toll-like receptors (TLRs) and lectins. They also express high levels of major histocompatibility complex (MHC) for presenting antigens to and activating T cells.

In response to microbes, dendritic cells are recruited to the T-cell zones of lymphoid organs. Here, they present antigens to T cells with help of MHC. 

Similar cells with dendritic morphology in the germinal centers of lymphoid follicles in the spleen and lymph nodes are follicular dendritic cells. They bear Fc receptors for IgG and receptors for C3b. Immature dendritic cells within the epidermis are called Langerhans cells.

Note:

  • Aggretope - part of the antigen associated with the MHC molecule on the antigen-presenting cell
  • Epitope - antigenic part of contact with the T-cell receptor

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about macrophages?

choices.text: It acts as an antigen presenting cell
It plays a role in humoral immunity
It plays a role in cell-mediated immunity
It is a component of innate immunity only

questions.solution:
Macrophages are components of both innate and acquired immunity.

They phagocytose microbes and protein antigens. They process the antigens and present the peptide fragments to T cells. Thus, macrophages function as antigen-presenting cells in T-cell activation.

They also participate in the effector phase of humoral immunity. Macrophages efficiently phagocytose and destroy microbes that are opsonized (coated) with IgG or C3b.

They are key effector cells in certain forms of cell-mediated immunity to eliminate intracellular microbes. In this type of response, T cells activate macrophages and enhance their ability to kill ingested microbes.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about natural killer cells?

choices.text: CD16 and CD56 are the surface molecules
They are involved in antibody-dependant cytotoxic killing
IL-12  stimulates the proliferation of NK cells
They activate macrophages by secreting IFN-Œ≥

questions.solution:
IL-2 and IL-15 stimulate the proliferation of NK cells. On the other hand, IL-12 activates the killing of target cells and secretion of IFN-γ.

NK cells are large granular lymphocytes, which constitutes 5% to 10% of peripheral blood lymphocytes. CD16 and CD56 are the surface molecules.

Functions of NK cells:

  • Killing of a variety of virus-infected cells and tumor cells, without prior exposure to or activation by these microbes or tumors
  • Secretion of interferon-γ (IFN-γ), which activates macrophages to destroy ingested microbes
  • Antibody-dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity (ADCC) - NK cells express CD16 which is a receptor for IgG Fc tails. Hence, these cells have the ability to lyse IgG-coated target cells. 

ADCC is also seen in immune responses involving neutrophils, eosinophils, macrophages, etc.

The image given below shows activating and inhibitory receptors of natural killer (NK) cells.

Note: A new group of T cells has been discovered called NK-T cells. These are T cells that contain markers of NK cells. These are important defence mechanisms against microorganisms like Listeria monocytogenes and Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

questions.text: Which of these is common to both cytotoxic T-cells and NK cells?

choices.text: They are MHC l restricted cells
Require antibodies to be present for action

questions.solution:
Both cytotoxic T-cells and NK cells are effective against virus-infected cells.

The NK cells have different mechanisms of action while killing target cells.

NK cells can lyse IgG-coated target cells by binding to the Fc tail of IgG, through the CD16 receptor expressed on NK cells. This phenomenon is known as antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC).

NK cells secrete various cytokines such as interferon-γ (IFN-γ), which activate macrophages to destroy ingested microbes.

Target cell destruction by NK cells is also mediated through two others receptors - activating receptors and inhibitory receptors.

The activating receptors enable NK cells to recognize infected and stressed cells. The inhibitory receptors recognize self class-I MHC molecules, that are expressed on all healthy cells thereby preventing NK cells from killing normal cells. Virus infection / neoplastic transformation overexpresses the activating receptors and simultaneously reduces the expression of class-I MHC molecules. As a result, NK cells are activated and the infected cells are killed.

CD8+ cytotoxic T lymphocytes directly kill damaged cells.

Non-antibody mediated killing / direct cytotoxicity

Kills virus-infected, neoplastic, and donor graft cells by apoptosis

Memory is absent Memory is present

questions.text: Which of the following markers on antigen-presenting cells function as costimulatory molecules for T cells?
questions.solution:
CD80 (B7-1) and CD86 (B7-2) are the costimulatory molecules present on antigen-presenting cells (APCs). They bind to CD28 protein present on T cells. This promotes the expansion of antigen-stimulated T cells and their differentiation into effector and memory cells.

T-cell activation requires two signals that are delivered by APCs. They include:

  1. Antigens displayed by APCs in the form of peptides bound to MHC molecules, that are recognised by T-cell receptors
  2. Costimulatory signal (as it stimulates T cells in conjunction with antigen) provided by molecules on APCs that engage particular costimulatory receptors on T cells

In the absence of costimulation, T cells that recognize antigen either fail to respond and die or enter a state of unresponsiveness known as anergy. Thus, costimulation is a key determinant of the outcome of a T-cell encounter with an antigen.

questions.text: Production of which of the following antibodies is induced by polysaccharides and lipids?
questions.solution:
Polysaccharides and lipids stimulate the secretion of mainly IgM antibodies.

B lymphocytes use their antigen receptors to recognize various types of antigens:

  • Proteins (through CD40L and cytokine-mediated helper T-cell actions) - induce production of IgG, IgA, IgE
  • Polysaccharides and lipids - induce production of IgM mainly

Helper T cells also help in antibodies by the mechanisms:

  • Stimulate formation of germinal centers which consist of proliferating B cells
  • Induce isotype switching through cytokines IFN-γ and IL-4
  • Affinity maturation - stimulate the production of antigen-specific antibodies 

Isotype switching and affinity maturation occur mainly in germinal centers.

questions.text: When papain acts on a molecule of immunoglobulin, which of the following are the end products?
questions.solution:
When papain acts on a molecule of immunoglobulin, the end products are 1 Fc and 2 Fab fragments.

If an antibody molecule is digested with papain, cleavage occurs above the disulfide bonds that hold the heavy chains together. This generates 3 separate fragments, two of which are called Fab (fragment antigen binding), and one of which is called Fc (fragment crystallizable).

The image given below shows the cleavage of immunoglobulin by papain.

Cleavage of the antibody molecule with pepsin generates one large fragment called F(ab´)2 and a digested Fc fragment.

The image given below shows the cleavage of immunoglobulin by pepsin.

questions.text: In which of the following cells is recirculation seen?

choices.text: Both plasma cells and T lymphocytes
Both B lymphocytes and plasma cells

questions.solution:
Lymphocyte recirculation is seen in T lymphocytes.

Migration of the lymphocytes between blood and lymphoid organs is called recirculation. Naive lymphocytes traverse the peripheral lymphoid organs, where immune responses are initiated. When antigen-presenting cells activate them, the effector lymphocytes migrate to sites of infection and inflammation. 

In contrast, plasma cells remain in lymphoid organs and the bone marrow. They do not need to migrate to sites of infection because they secrete antibodies that are carried to distant tissues.

questions.text: Among the following, which cells have MHC class II?

choices.text: B cells, dendritic cells, mononuclear phagocytes

questions.solution:
Class II major histocompatibility¬†complex (MHC) molecules are mainly expressed on¬†macrophages, B lymphocytes, and dendritic cells. These cells present ingested antigens to T-cells.

The function of MHC molecules is to display¬†peptide fragments of protein antigens for recognition by antigen-specific T cells.¬†In humans, the MHC molecules are called human leukocyte antigens (HLA)¬†because they were initially detected on leukocytes by the binding of antibodies. The combination of HLA alleles in each individual is called the HLA haplotype.

The genes encoding HLA molecules are clustered on the short arm of chromosome 6.¬†

Uses¬†of MHC/¬†HLA typing¬†include:

  • Anthropology
  • Transfusion
  • Paternity testing
  • Forensic science
  • Transplantation
  • Disease correlation

questions.text: Which of the following is not encoded by MHC class III genes?
questions.solution:
β2 microglobulin associated cell surface molecules are encoded by MHC class I and not class III.

Class III MHC molecules include:

  • Complement proteins (such as C2, C4, and B factor)
  • Cytokines (such as TNF-α, LTA, and LTB)
  • Properdin factor BQ of alternate pathway
  • Enzyme tyrosine hydroxylase
  • Heat-shock proteins

Class III molecules are encoded by genes located between those that encode class I and class II molecules.
